title: How to tell if a transformation is linear - Quora

response.answer_text: A linear transformation has two properties. Otherwise, it is non-linear. Linear Transformation A linear operator [math]f(x)[/math] satisfies these two properties. [math]f(x)[/math] is a linear transformation. The transformation of a sum [math]f(x+y) = f(x) + f(y)[/math]The transformation pulls out a constant [math]f(ax) = af(x)[/math]Examples In Calculus, the derivative is a linear operator. [math]\frac{d}{dx}(x+y) = \frac{dx}{dx} + \frac{dy}{dx} = 1 + \frac{dy}{dx}[/math] Cartesian lines are of course linear. [math]ax + by = c[/math] is a two-dimensional line [math]ax + by + cz = d[/math] is a three-dimensional line Non-Linear Example Polynomials other than lines are non-linear. A quadratic polynomial [math](y+z)^2[/math] creates a new term [math]2yz[/math]. [math]p(x) = x^2[/math] [math]p(y+z) = (y+z)^2 = y^2 + 2yz + z^2 \ne (y^2 + z^2)[/math]

Linearity is a combination of two properties. A map [math]f[/math] is linear if [math]f(\alpha x) = \alpha f(x)[/math]Scaling the input is the same thing as scaling the output.[math]f(x+y) = f(x) + f(y)[/math]We can add and then take the mapping, or we can add after we map each of the parts. This is known as a homomorphism.When we put these rules together we get [math]f(\alpha x + \beta y) = \alpha f(x) + \beta f(y)[/math] Or more generally [math]f(\sum_j \alpha_j x_j) = \sum_j \alpha_j f(x_j)[/math] A map is linear if it takes linear combinations of [math]x_j [/math]to linear combinations of [math]f(x_j)[/math] with the same coefficients. To prove that a map is linear you just have to show one of these equivalent conditions.

A map f:A->B is linear if for all x,y in A and m in R say, then f(x+m.y) = f(x) + m.f(y). Note that this definition simultaneously imposes the two conditions :- f(x+y) = f(x) +f(y) and f(m.x) = m.f(x)
